Copilot for Word, Excel & PowerPoint

Microsoft 365 Copilot brings AI assistance into the Office apps you already use. Below is a concise, practical overview of what Copilot does in each app, how to think about prompts, and where it shines.

Word

Copilot in Word — Draft, refine, and reformat

Use Copilot to quickly create first drafts, rewrite for tone or length, and generate outlines and summaries from your files.

Great for

  • Turning bullet notes into a structured document (memos, SOPs, briefs)
  • Rewriting for tone: concise, executive, persuasive, or plain language
  • Summarizing long docs and extracting action items
  • Creating templates and filling in missing sections
Example prompt: “Draft a one‑page executive summary of the attached project brief. Keep it under 250 words, plain language, and include 3 bullets of key risks.”
Tips: Mention audience and length; attach/source the reference document; ask for a list of assumptions so you can correct it.
Excel

Copilot in Excel — Explore, explain, and simulate

Copilot helps you analyze tables, spot trends, create scenarios, and describe what formulas or pivots are doing in plain English.

Great for

  • Explaining variances and trends across time or categories
  • Building what‑if scenarios and quick sensitivity tables
  • Creating drafts of pivot tables and charts
  • Describing formulas and cleaning data (identify duplicates, missing values)
Example prompt: “Analyze revenue by region for the last 6 quarters. Create a summary with drivers of growth and a simple chart. Flag any outliers.”
Tips: Name your tables; describe the goal and timeframe; ask Copilot to explain results step‑by‑step so you can audit them.
PowerPoint

Copilot in PowerPoint — Build and polish slides

Start from a document or outline and let Copilot produce a themed deck; then iterate on visuals, speaker notes, and time‑boxed edits.

Great for

  • Generating a first‑cut deck from a Word doc or meeting notes
  • Refining layouts, speaker notes, and slide titles
  • Creating alternative versions for different audiences
  • Producing a quick 3–5 slide summary for briefings
Example prompt: “Create 6 slides from this Word doc for an executive audience. Use a simple style, add concise speaker notes, and end with 3 decision options.”
Tips: Specify slide count and audience; request “one idea per slide”; ask for alternative layouts or a summary deck.

Prompting Basics

  • Context: Provide source files or paste key text. Name the audience and goal.
  • Constraints: Specify length, tone, formats (e.g., bullets, table, slide count).
  • Critique: Ask Copilot to list assumptions and open questions; iterate with Refine.

Remember to review outputs for accuracy, compliance, and organization‑specific terminology before sharing.

High‑level overview prepared for quick onboarding to Copilot in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint.
